title: Pep Guardiola refuses to blame his shaky defence as Manchester City are knocked out Champions League
text:
Sport Pep Guardiola refuses to blame his shaky defence as Manchester City are knocked out Champions League The Spaniard insisted he has more pressing things to consider immediately after the Monaco game than his defenders Share Click   Pep refuses to blame his defense after crashing out to Monaco Share this video Get football   Thank you for subscribing!   
Pep Guardiola refused to blame his shaky defence as Manchester City were dumped out the Champions League at the last-16 stage. 
Guardiola, marking his 100th game in European football, watched as his side threw away their 5-3 advantage from the first leg at the Etihad. 
Goals from Kylian Mbappe and Fabinho saw Monaco storm into a two-goal lead before Leroy Sane looked to have clinched it with a 71st minute strike. 
But Monaco had the last laugh through Tiemoue Bakayoko, whose late goal ensured the French giants would be progressing to the quarter-finals of the competition. Pep Guardiola refused to blame his shaky defence against Monaco (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
The City defence were run ragged throughout the game as they failed to contain the talented pairing of Mbappe and Bernado Silva. 
And not for the first time this season, they conceded sloppy goals while apparently looking to outscore the opposition. 
Guardiola was asked whether his back-four and keeper were to blame for his squad failing to progress in the Champions League, as you can see in the above video. Guardiola shouts instructions to John Stones in the last-16 clash (Photo: Getty) 
But the former Barcelona and Bayern Munich boss claimed there was another reason. 
"It's not about defence, you always complain about keepers and defence," said Guardiola. 
"The problem was that in the first half we were not there, our strength when we have the ball is to be aggressive, but we didn't. 
"We have done it all season, but in that moment we didn't. That is why we are out, we played for 45 minutes, but you have to play for more than that. The Spaniard said his side only turned up for 45 minutes of the second leg (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
"But it is not about the defence and the goalkeeper. 
"Obviously, you cannot spend 90 minutes like we were in the second half, but the gap between the first and the second was too big." 
"But we will learn, the situation will help us in the future." poll loading Will Manchester City win the Champions League while Pep Guardiola is in charge? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
